Kali-lowmem.description: Kali Linux is a Debian-derived Linux distribution designed for digital forensics and penetration testing.
Kali-lowmem.name: public.ecr.aws/bramblethorn/kasm/kali:1.16.1-rolling-weekly
Kali-lowmem.notes:
This low memory workspace is allocated 1536MB of RAM.

This Kali workspace extends the Kasm Kali workspace as follows:
  - password-less sudo
  - more packages including Burp Suite Pro, Postman, ZAP weekly, Caido
  - VPN sidecar support when the VPN network device is bound to x.x.x.2

If a network is selected where the x.x.x.2 address is a gateway, traffic will be routed through it. This allows a VPN to run as a container and be shared across containers.

Let's Encrypt.description:
This container sets up an Nginx webserver and reverse proxy with php support and a built-in letsencrypt client that automates free SSL server certificate generation and renewal processes. It also contains fail2ban for intrusion prevention.
  
  Before running this container, make sure that the url and subdomains are properly forwarded to this container's host.
  
  - Port 443 on the internet side of the router should be forwarded to this container's port 443.
  - If you need a dynamic dns provider, you can use the free provider duckdns.org where the url will be yoursubdomain.duckdns.org and the subdomains    can be www,ftp,cloud
  - The container detects changes to url and subdomains, revokes existing certs and generates new ones during start. 
  - It also detects changes to the DHLEVEL parameter and replaces the dhparams file.
  
  - If you'd like to password protect your sites, you can use htpasswd. Run the following command on your host to generate the htpasswd file docker exec -it letsencrypt htpasswd -c /config/nginx/.htpasswd <username>

Follow the article here

When the installation is complete, navigate to your.ip.goes.here:1010/admin. Follow the article here if you run into issues binding to port 53. For extra information on this container visit the mainteiner GitHub Page. You can add ports: 5335 to access Ubound externally; 22 to enable SSH; 67 to use DHCP Server. Add those ports in Show advanced options. if you run into issues binding to port 53. If you like to use Pi-Hole's built in DHCP-Server change the Network type to host and open advance options and scroll to Labels and add: NET_ADMIN with the value True. When you do so, specify a port is no more needed, navigate to your.ip.goes.here/admin.

Docker-Rootless-Ubuntu-Noble.description: Rootless Docker in Docker Desktop image Ubuntu Noble based.
Docker-Rootless-Ubuntu-Noble.notes:
The Kasm Docker Rootless Ubuntu Noble Workspace requires libseccomp => 2.5.3 and Linux Kernel 6.3+ to run.

This can be checked by running runc --version

If you still want to run Docker Rootless Ubuntu Noble but do not have the minimum required libseccomp version, it can be run in an unsecure manner by adding: {"security_opt":["seccomp=unconfined"]} to the Docker Run Config Override (JSON) setting above.

NOTE: This will run the Workspace without the docker seccomp sandbox and will significantly reduce the amount of protection that Kasm Workspaces can provide.

For Ubuntu Noble hosts, Docker-in-Docker rootless images require the rootlesskit AppArmor profile. Include the following in your Docker Run Config Override (JSON) for your workspace to function properly: {"security_opt":["apparmor=rootlesskit"]}

Chromium.notes:
The Kasm Ubuntu Jammy Workspace requires libseccomp => 2.5.3 to run.

This can be checked by running runc --version

If you still want to run Ubuntu Jammy but do not have the minimum required libseccomp version, it can be run in an unsecure manner by adding: {"security_opt":["seccomp=unconfined"]} to the Docker Run Config Override (JSON) setting above.

NOTE: This will run the Workspace without the docker seccomp sandbox and will significantly reduce the amount of protection that Kasm Workspaces can provide.
